column1: It is easy to argue, invoking self - righteous precedents, that the lady who hurries to assist the injured animal or pedestrian in the street or who feeds the beggar on her doorstep, but who fails to get excited about suffering in general and shows a disinclination to contribute to Oxfam, is really not a good Samaritan ; that she is morally short - sighted in letting ‘ distance’ be a factor, and that she should be equally concerned for suffering whenever and wherever.
